div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 4 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Photographers. REISER & BINDER Photographers.
div.p: 26848 Alexandria & Cairo. 4-12 906
THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. div.head: THE GRANT TO LORD CROMER.
div.p: The substantial majority by which was voted a grant of £50,000 to the Earl ofCromer in

onsideration of his eminent services as Agent and Consul-General in Egypt will be felt by t|ie public to give appropriate expression to a national sentiment. In the pages <»f hiStory Lord Cromer's splendid work in Egypt, says the "Times", will shed lustre upon the a^e in which it was performed, and, arno^ things of less intrinsic value and things which we could afford to forget altogether will shine forth as a vindication of u,ir claim to have shown the world what is b^t and noblest in Imperial achievement. T|ie nation owes it to itself not less than to Lord Cromer to make some signal recognition of services which enhance the national reputation by their powerful appeal to the moral sense of the civilized world. For the effect of that appeal the nation does not wait upon the judgment of posterity. It has been approved by one of the most remarkable and beneficent changes in our international relations which this generation baa witnessed. This country is now in actual enjoyment of a close friendship with France which has been rendered possible by the tact, the patience, and the inflexible justice of Lord Cromer's conduct of affairs through a particularly critical time and in p» ; liarly difficult circumstances. We might have a great ruler of Egypt conferring immense benefits upon her people, and doing valuable service to his country, yet failing to add the supreme service of conciliating a proud and sensitive nation, and of converting antagonism and suspicion into friendship and confidence. That task had to be accomplished in Egypt, otherwise no efforts in other quarters could have fully succeeded, and that it was accomplished is due to Lord Cromer's personal qualities and to the undeviating constancy with which he made its accomplishment one of the cardinal aims of his life. Nor does that achievement, great as it is, exhaust the force of the moral appeal. For there were other nations besides France on the alert to find some weak spot in the administration of Egypt, and to pounce upon any defeot, even of manner, as an excuse for creating serious embarassment.

There are plenty of precedents for making substantial awards to successful soldiers and sailors, but not so many for recognizing in this manner the merits of civil administrators. The reason may be in part that the time was when great civil administrators became rich during the course of theiradministration by some automatic process which did not arouse much curiosity. But in part the reason probably is that mankind have been accustomed to think much more highly of the art of warand of the qualities of a greatcommanderthanofthelessshowy but more beneficient art of peace and the qualities of a great administrator. It accords with the fitness of things that a Government which in other directions is protesting against great armaments, and by implication against the habit of mind that glorifies those who employ them, should offer a recognition of greatness in the art of peaceful and beneficent rule more substantial and conspicuous than has yet been given in our history. By enlarging precedent in this direction it emphasizes the change of attitude which it recommends to this and other countries, and perhaps does more than can be done by any verbal protestations to persuade other people of the seriousness of its views. It is all the more regrettable that a certain section of its supporters has already intimated an intention to oppose the grant to Lord Cromer when it comes up for discussion on Tuesday. Wecan only hope that opposition will be limited to a section which makes no secret of its hostility to anything that may redound to the credit or advantage of this country. It is one of the incidental merits of Lord Cromer's administration ol Egypt that he has been too singleminded and too absolutely preoccupied with the great international and administrative aims that he set before himself from the first over to have done anything that could arouse the susceptibilities of either English party. He has been a servant of the Crown and the nation in a sense so full and complete that there is no room tor a trace of party feeling in considering His Majesty's recommendation.

If we must glance at what may be called the business side of the matter, it may be observed that distinguished public servants are rewarded with honours conferred by the Sovereign, and that money awards are ancillary to these honours. They are intended to prevent the honouxs from being a grievous burden to those upon whom they are conferred, and thus to avoid the conversion of reward into mockery. An earldom is a worse than barren reward unless a man is enabled to support his station in a becoming manner. Lord Cromer went te Egypt a man far from rich, and it is gencrall) believed that he has left it a poorer man Had he applied his groat business abilities to his own affairs instead of to those of the country during the last quarter of a century, no one can doubt that he would have made bimselt with less labour wealthy enough either to take an earldom or to do very well without it. He has been made an earl as part of the general arrangements by which the nation expresses its sense of what is fitting and beeom ing, and the grant now made is merely the logical complement of what has already been done.

div.head: Cuards Reinforcements for Egypt.
div.p: It has been decided to semi a strong reinforcement to the 3rd Battalion of the Coldstream Guards in Egypt. The battalion was noted for disliandment with the 3rd Scots Guards, broken up at the end of last year.

div.head: Delr el Bahari.
div.p: Professor Edouard Naville delivered a lec ture, at King's College Strand, on the 29th ult., on the recently discovered Xlth Dynasty temple, at Deir el Bahari, in connexion with the Exhibition of Antiquities now being held at the college by the Egypt Exploration Fund.

div.head: Now Barraoks.
div.p: Credits of L.E. 30,000 and L.E. 5,000 have been opened for the construction of barracks at Abliasieh and Ras el Tin, respectively, and, as previously reported, L.E. 400,000 are to spe spent upon the construction of new barracks at Abbasieh for the Army of Occupation.

div.head: An Esbekleh Row.
div.p: A free fight took place in the Esbekieh quarter of Cairo on Tuesday evening at midnight lietween several intoxicated Europeans and a crowd of native cab drivers. Five persons received nasty wounds on the bead from flying glass and chairs, and the police were called upon to interfere twice before order was eventually restored.

div.head: The Follies.
div.p: As announced by us yesterday "The Follies" will make their dl*but at the Abbas theatre in Cairo on Monday. "The Follies" met with great success in Calcutta where they delighted the patrons of the Theatre Royal, and every item on the programme nightly was voci ferously encored. The drolleries of the ven triloquist with his doll "Tommy" were the cause of much merriment.

div.head: Appeal for Respite.
div.p: Soli man Eff. Fahmy, who was sentenced to a fine of L.E. 100 and 6 months imprison ment, as reported by us yesterday, presented himself to day at the Native Court of Appeal with the request that he might be allowed three days' respite, in order to arrange his affairs liefore undergoing his sentence. Per mission was, however, refused and he was immediately taken into custody.

div.head: Capture of Caravan.
div.p: A detachment of the Coast Guards, under the command of Mulazim Tani Mohamed Eff. Saleh, effected a clever capture of a Bedouin caravan, which was carrying contraband from the West frontier towards the "Reef." Among the articles of contraband which were seized were 20 sacks of hashish, containing about 1.300 kilos, 8 rifles and 600 rounds of ammunition. Eight Bedouinsand 17 camels were also raptured.

div.head: Army of Occupation.
div.p: The following notice has been drawn up by the military authorities relating to districts infected with plague "The attention of all concerned is directed to District Order 469 of 7th instant, regarding the forwarding of nominal rolls of daily arrivals from plague districts, which must be strictly complied with. Owing to the recent plague cases at Damanhour, Behera Province, officers commanding units are held responsible that all N.C.O.'s and men returning from that province off leave are immediately medically inspected on their arrival and for 7 days following.

div.head: Ras El-Tln School.
div.p: The "Egyptian Standard" says : "We are informed by a gentleman who is in a position to know, as he was the object of the advice himself, that the teachers of English in Ras-el-Tin School advise the students not to read the "Egyptian Standard." The reason advanced i- that its English would corrupt the pure style that is required in Ras-el-Tin School. When it was objected that the editors of the paper had every opportunity of knowing English well, one of the teachers remarked "don't you believe it. The paper is edited by Egyptians'" This is the manner in which the Dunlopites inculcate the duties of patriotism'."

div.head: THE KING AND LORD CROMER.
MESSAGE TO PARLIAMENT .
div.p: As announced in our cable of the 25th the message from the throne expressing his Majesty's recognition of Lord Cromer's services to Egypt, ami recommending a money grant of £50,000 to his lordship was read in both houses of Parliament on Wednesday last.
The Lord Chancellor read the King's message to the House of Lords, which was as follows :—

"His Majesty, having taken into consideration the eminent services rendered by Earl Cromer, former Agent and Consul-General in Egypt, and being desirous in recognition of such services to confer upon him some signal mark of his favour, recommends to the House of Lords that they do concur in granting Lord Cromer the sum of fifty thousand pounds," (Hear, hear.)

In the House of Commons Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman, who was standing at the Bar, having been called upon by the Speaker, said :— A message from the King, Sir, signed by his Majesty's own hand. (Cheers.)
The right lion, gentleman then advanced up the floor of the House and handed his Majesty's message to.

The Speaker, who read it to the House as follows :—His Majesty, taking into consideration the eminent services rendered by the Earl of Cromer, formerly Agent and Consul-General in Egypt, and being desirous, in recognition of such services, to confer on him some signal mark of his favour, recommends to his faithful Commons that he should be enabled to grant to I/ord Cromer the sum of £50,000. (Cheers, ami some cries of "Oh.")
Sir II. (-ampbell Bannerman. —I beg to move, Sir, that his Majesty's gracious message be referred to Committee of Supply. ("Hear, hear," and some bon. members, "No.")
Mr. W. Redmond.—May I ask the right lion, gentleman when it is likely that this grant will come up for discussion ?
Sir. H. Campbell Bannerman.—On Tuesday next, Sir.
Mr. W. Redmond.--1 beg to give that I will oppose it. (Hear, hear.)
The motion was then agreed to.
The interesting ceremony connected with the presentation of the Royal message is thus described by the "Manchester Guar dian's" Parliamentary correspondent : —

Noble Jjords as well as lowly Commoners had to be reminded to-night that a message from the King, "signed with His Majesty's own hand," could not properly be delivered to an assembly with all its hats on. The reminder, of course, was conveyed without ostentation, and in one or two cases without eflect. In the Commons senior members, seeing the Prime Minister waiting at the bar with a sheet of paper in his hand and utilising it as a fan, were able to warn the awe-struck novices that this must be a Royal message, and that such occasions called for an uncovered head. Presently Liberal leader was to he observed nailing to the Speaker, his paper fan being turned to the uses ot a semaphore, message from the King, sir, signed with Majesty's own hand," called Sir Henry, advancing up the floor with the document, which, on being unfolded, turned out to he a recommendation to the Commons to make a grant of £50,000 to Iiord Cromer. Although Mr. William Redmond promptly gave notice of his intention to oppose the grants the Irish mem hers, it may be noted, were among the first to comply with the etiquette of the occasion. A message to the other House to "concur" in the grant found more than one experienced courtier remiss in his duty. The confusion of the culprits when nudged into consciousness of their lapse may be imagined.

div.head: NILE VALLEY.
div.p: A general meeting of the Nile Valley pany (Limited), in liquidation, yesterday at Winchester House, E. C., for the purpose of receiving the liquidators accounts, showing the manner in which the winding up had been effected, and the property disposed of, and also to fix the remuneration of the liquidator.

Mr. J. Pasfield (liquidator) presided, and stated that the liquidation would have been completed earlier but for the tact that there wils a twelve months option which had to expire, and which subsequently turned out to bo worth nothing. The creditors amounted to £12,523, and, unfortunately, there were some dissentient shareholders who did not accept the offer made regarding their shares, and the matter went to arbitration. These shareholders won the day, and the cost of this amounted to £125. After all the necessary payments had been made, there was a deficiency of £l,141, which was met by the Nile Valley (New) Company (Limited). The shareholders who did not come into the reconstruction, but who did not dissent, represented 5,317 shares, and accordingly tliej' were sold, and realised £1,356, making a total of £1,363 with the interest accrued.
The liquidator's report was unanimously adopted. Upon the motion of Mr. R. J. Price, M.P., seconded by Mr. 8. Wileman, a sum of 200 guineas was voted to the liquidator as remuneration.

div.head: BIRTHS AND DEATHS.
div.p: During the week ending the 29th July, 505 births, 11 of which were of European parentage, and 748 deaths, 14 of which were Europeans, were registered in Cairo. 56.3 of the deaths were of children under 5 years of age. The principal causes of death, with the number of victims, were dyphteria 2, typhus 5, measles 23, small-pox 1, erysipelas 2, and fever 2.

div.head: ENGLISH RULE IN EGYPT.
INTERVIEW WITH HOUSNI BEY.
div.p: The following is a full account of the interview with Housni Bey by a correspondent i of the " Pall Mall Gazette ", a summary of which appeared in our special telegram of the 25th inst. :—

I have recently had a conversation with a highly placed and very intelligent Egyptian, Atta Housni Bey, who is a cousin by marriage of the Khedive. Housni Bey belongs to the Moderate Reform party in Egypt. His Excellency speaks no European language with any facility, so that the conversation had to be carried on in^Arabic with the aid of an interpreter. I found that the Bey considered that the Nationalist movement had taken on an exaggerated phase. "It is absurd to criticise everything the English do merely because it is they who do it," he said. "The English have performed much service to my country. It is natural from the geographical position, that they cannot abandon us; we are in the route to India, the gateway to the Dark Continent. I quite understand the paramount necessity to England of remaining in Egypt*; at the same time, I think the scope of area of local government should be enlarged.
"Ijord Cromer's administration was good from the financial point of view, but his influence was damaged by the severity shown in the Denshawi affair.

"The present crisis in Egyptian feeling is due to the latter policy of England to concentrate all the European influences in her own hands, and to withdraw the country from the influence of other nations, also in the reluctance to give the natives opportunities under the British flag."

Speaking of world politics as they aftected Egypt, Housni Bey insisted on the value of friendship between England and Turkey. The tendency of the Liberal Press in England to cry out against the Sultan was a mischievous tendency, he thought, because it drove Turkey into the Arms of Germany. "We Mussulmans acknowledge the Sultan as the representative of the Caliphate, as the successor of the Mahomet, and in that religious sense, of course, other rulers, which destiny may give us, are merely pseudo-caliphs."

In order to bring out the self reliance of the native, and hasten the day when Parliamentary institutions can be established— t he Bey does not believe that the day has yet fully come—it is necessary to develope the education of the native. His Excellency thought that the English might show a greater interest in higher education, and favour such an idea as the University at Cairo. The school system was greatly extending; the fellaheen were even sending their daughters to be educated, but instruction remained in too elementary a state.

He complained that two faults had been committed in Egypt in breaking down all distinctions of class, so that the man who had natural authority was largely robbed of it, and in taking away from public education those higher institutions that existed before the occupation. Nevertheless, the instruction of the people was making great progress, and he thought that in five years forty per cent., of the children would lx? able to read and write instead of ten per cent, which was now the case. In dealing with education, he insisted that the scholars should be better grounded in Arabic before being t-aight the sciences in English, in the Secondary Schools.

The Bey is anxious to have an audience with King Edward. "I ask this not for a political purpose- I am more / an educationist and a publicist than a politician—but in a purely personal capacity. I wish to see the Great Emperor under whose flag I live and who rules over three hundred millions of people. I fully recognise that we must be protected by some nation, and it is proper that England should have moral, financial, and military control. But let her take us a little more into her confidence, ami she will find the results are good for the' happiness of the country."

The Bey, who is a somewhat bulky-look-ing man in the thirties, with a pleasant and intelligent expression, leant back smiling benevolently and lighted a cigarette. "1 hope my views commend themselves to you," he said. "What a pity," observed his inteq^reter and physician, Dr. Tabet Bey, who has learnt excellent English in the American Presbyterian College at Beyrouth i Syria, "they would only allow his Excellency to bring in a box of a hundred cigarettes."
And thus in a genial triviality the conversation came to an end.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN LAND ALLOTMENT COMPANY.
div.p: The first balance sheet of the Agricultural Bank of Cyprus, extending over a period of eight months, ending 30th June 1907, shows a great development of business, which is in fact very similar to the first beginnings of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt. The total amount of loans A. (for one year) is £233 ; for loans B. (for long periods) £41,063.10. The number of Debitors is 961, so that the average amount of a single loan comes to about £43. The interest on all outstandingloans amountst(^£26.089.9 2. The peasants of the island begin to understand the great advantages offered to them by this new establishment, and the staff of the Agricultural Bank has already done splendid work. The Bank, having a considerable cash capital at its disposal, is therefore well equipped to meet the requirements of agriculturists in the coining winter season.

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT.
COST OF LIVING.
div.p: The following are among the questions con cerning Egypt which have recently been put before Sir Edward Grey

Mr. MacNeill.—To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he is aware that a number of inferior functionaries of the Egyptian Government have petitioned Sir Eldon Gorst to the effect that the cost of living in Egypt is constantly and rapidly increasing, that their salaries were fixed on the basis of much lower costs of former years and are no longer sufficient for maintenance; and that the Commission appointed by Lord Cromer in 1904, by making the maximum of wages in the highest class from £5 to £9 per month, the maximum of which cannot be reached , in less than 14 years, has rendered their condition worse than formerly; and whether he will recommend the Egyptian Government th revise the scale.

Sir E. Grey.—— I am aware that this subject has ' been toeebpying the attention of the Egyptian Government But I /do not consider it advisable for H.M. Government to interfere in a matter which obviously depends upon detailed information of local conditions, with which the Egyptian Government are fully qualified to deal.
BARRISTERS IN NATIVE COURTS.

Mr. MacNeil.—To ask .the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he is aware that the council of discipline, which tries barristers practising in the Native counts of Egypt is at present wholly composed of judges and the Procureur General in his quality of magistrate; and whether he will advise the Egyptian Government to secure for the Bar adequate representation upon such council.
Sir E. Grey.—The question is one of ad ministrative detail which must be left to the Egyptian Government.
DEFENSE OF NATIVE PRISONERS. Mr.

State aware tising are compelled to defend prisoners gratuitously ; whether upon failure to appear for the defence after selection by the court, a fine of £50 may be inflicted upon them and whether he will advise the Egyptian Government to alter the system.
Sir E Grey.—I am not aware of the system which obtains in regard to this point; but I do not see that 1 can advantageously interfere in a matter of this kind. THE LAMBERT AFFAIR.

Dr. Rutherford. — To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether the Government of France have made any representations to His Majesty's Government on the Lambert afiai'r; whether the Government of France considers Mr. Dunlop's action as contrary to the spirit of the treaty of 1904 ; and whether, in the interests of the entente cordiale, His Majesty's Government will recommend the Government of Egypt to re appoint M Lambert as principal of the Khedivial Law School, or, failing him, to consult the wishes of the French Government.
Sir E. Grey. — No representations have been made by the French Government, and my Right Hon. friend has nothing to add to the answer given to the Hon. Member on the 16th inst.
THE TRIPOLI FRONTIER.

Mr. John Robertson.—To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether he has any official information showing that in the first week in June a detachment of 50 Turkish troops occupied Bemba, on the frontier of Tripoli, and that the Egyptian Government had charged an officer of the garrison of Alexandria to proceed to the spot with a detachment and cause it to be evacuated . and whether he can state what has since occurred.
Sir E. Grey.—The answer to the first question is in the affirmative. An officer went to investigate and by June 8th. was able to report that the Turkish patrol left Egyptian territory.
LORD CROMERS PENSION.

Mr. Kettle asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs last Thursday whether Lord Cromer was entitled to and had obtained a pension on his retirement; and, if so, what was the amount of this pension, and was it charged on Imperial 1 or Egyptian funds.

Sir E. Grey: A pension of £900 a y6ar has l)een granted to Lord Cromer from Imperial funds. This is the pension attached by the hitherto existing rules to service as Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General in Egypt: The pension eatned in other posts of corresponding importance, such as embassies, is £1,700 a year.

div.head: IVORY AUCTIONS.
div.p: The quarterly ivory sales were held in Ixm-don last week, 66 1/4 tons being offered against 39 A tons at die same period last year. This includetl 24 i tons Egyptian (20 tons Alexandrian and 4 J tons Malta), and 9 tens Abyssinian. There was a good competition and prices were well maintained. The demand was general for America, the Continent and the home trade. Billiard ball ivory continues in demand and measured pieces showed an advance of 10l per cwt on the average. The quantity catalogued was about the average, Egyptian again being in good supply. Abyssinian met a good demand at firm prices to 1Z to 2/ V cwt higher on medium tusks. Ball scrivelloks firm to rather dearer. Scrivelloes steady. Egyptian : Soft steady, occasionally a little easier hard steady to 2l V owt lower.

div.head: EGTPTIAN ESTATES, LIMITED.
SECOND ANNUAL MEETING.
div.p: The Second Annual General Meeting of this company was held on Friday last, the 26th at Winchester House, the Chairman, Mr. Gre-ville H. Palmer presiding.
After the notice convening the meeting had been read, the Chairman delivered the following speech Gentlemen,

We appear before you to-day in circumstances which have no parallel in my business experience. We are trading in a rich country, our trading has been successful to an extent that is quite remarkable, we have presented to you a balance-sheet showing, for the second time in the history of the Company, a very large profit, and yet we have to meet you with the very disappointing statement that we do not at present recommend the payment of a Dividend.

The reason is, that notwithstanding the general prosperity of the couptry, money in Egypt M very scarce. It is very difficult to borrow money even on the best of security,and therefore for the present we have to utilise all our available funds for our current requirements. These are will continue to be this year.

We are engaged in building operations on Savoy Chambers, and besides that we have to find money for the development of our Agricultural properties, without which they cannot be brought into a paying condition.

You will say; why do you not realise some of your assets ? and the answer is that it is difficult to make realizations on a large scale at the present moment. People with large sums available are not to be found at every corner. Real property in Egypt has not, so far as can be ascertained, fallen in value to any appreciable extent. So far from that being the case, wherever we have been able to trace sales of real property at all comparable to our own holdings, the values are fully* maintained, and even enhanced,-but the majority of such sales are of small parcels, and sales of large properties as a whole are for the moment almost entirely suspended. It is therefore obvious that we cannot raise such a sum of money as would be required for the payment of a dividend in this manner, not because the properties are not worth the price they are valued at, but because the buyers are tew and far between.

The financial position in Egypt to-day is a very remarkable one. You will remember that when we last met 1 told you that I did not believe in the pessimistic views of people in general, and in this country in particular, who were predicting a slump in land values in Egypt. These predictions have been per sistently indulged in ever since, and as far as the value of real property is concerned the slump has not come, nor does it at present shew any signs of doing so.
At the risk of wearying you I must say one or two more words about land values, especially as they apply in our own case.

There have been numerous articles in the Egyptian and European papers during the last few months, attempting to prove that the slump has at last come, but when they proceed to give illustrations, you will find that their instances are almost entirely confined to suburban properties. I have heard of no instances where agricultural lands or choice town lots have fallen in value, but rather the contrary, and to these two classes our investment are confined, with very trifling exceptions. You will remember that when we met last year, I made this very point, viz : that too high prices had been paid for this class of property (suburban) and that we were entirely free from dangerous investments of i this nature. I am very pleased to he able to i renew that assurance now. Our investipents i are not only worth every penny we have paid ; for them, but the valuation we have put upon them nt the date of the balance-sheet, a > valuation which, I am satisfied, holds good to-• day, shows a large increase on the cost price, i at which they stand on our books, and in the I balance-sheet. I may add that we hold agricultural estates which, when developed, will on a moderate estimate represent a value of b themselves alone equal to the share and r debenture capital.

i We have to inform yon that we are t gotiating for a rearrangement of our | benture capital, which, while it gives creased security and satisfaction to the benture holders, will at the same time give us a surplus amount of debentures of a more marketable nature, which will Iks at our disposal for the purposes of our business.

We are also asking you for powers to increase the ordinary share capital. We have no intention of making a public issue but we have found it so convenient in the past to have shares at our disposal for our business, that we wish to continue the practice. In fact a great part of our reserve has been built up in this way.

At the close of the Chairman's remarks, Mr. R. Lang Anderson, of the Advisory Board in Egypt, replied to several questions asked by shareholders, and stated that the value ol the Company's property as shown .in the balance sheet bad been absolutely maintained, and that it would not be necessary to write anything off their value for depreciation. As regards the depreciation in the shares, this the Board naturally could not control, What had undoubtedly helped to contribute to the depreciation in prices of shares was due to the fact that a great deal of speculation had taken place in Egypt in the shares of the numerous companies that had been recently floated there and Estates shares being one of the few liquid shares had to be sold in order to enable the holders to meet their commitments elsewhere.
but as far as the properties of the Estates Company were conoerned, there was absolutely no depreciation in their values. The report and balance sheet were adopted.

But there has been financial trouble of another nature. People thought that because Egypt was prosperous, and money was flowing into the country from the sale of its agricultural products, this money would benefit rhe industrial condition of the country generally. In this the business community in Egypt has been woefully mistaken. The rush of industrial companies has resulted in financial trouble which has been widespread, and to this extent, and this only, have the prophets of evil been justified. The1 difficulties I have alluded to have affected all Companies, good and bad, for the pimple reason that the supply of cash on the market has not been enough to go round. It is a fact that last season, I believe, no less a sum than £25,000,006 went into the pockets of the Egyptian people as the proceeds of the cotton crop, and thia year I believe even a larger sum will go in the same direction, but the strange fact remains that it did not last year alleviate the financial strain, and I doubt very much if it will do so this. The fellaheen, who reoeive the money, do not put it into circulation ; they either buy or lease land with it, or they bury it, and the only portion of it that benefits the European community in any way is suefy amounts as are paid to the Government for taxes etc. and these sums are only paid out by degrees as the expenditure require them.

I said just now that this stringency of money has effected all Companies, good and bad. The bad ones found their subscribers unable to meet their capital, while the good Companies, (among wh^m I trust I may class our own,) have to strain their resources, and borrow money at high rates to carry on their business. You must remember that we are yet a young Company, and although I hope it will not be long before we are in receipt of a steady income from our properties, there is still a certain amount of development work and building to be done before this end is attained. Had financial matters taken the course which I think we were all justified in expecting from the general prosperity, of the ooantry, we should have been able to get cheap money, and we should not have luwl to ask the Shareholders to mike the present sacrifice. But we all reckoned without the ultra-Toryism of the fellaheen. They have not yet come to realise • the value of money ; they have got land hunger to an extent only to be paralleled, I should imagine, in Ireland ; and failing the appeasement of that hunger, they are just as prone to bury their money as tliey were in the days of Ismail Pasha. And so we get no benefit out of it.

This is my own view of the strange state of Egyptian finance. I own I was last year too apt to ridicule the pessimistic utteranoes to which I then alluded, but so far as I did so in relation to the predicted land slump, I contend that I was, and am still right, and that although trouble has come, it is ot an entirely different nature to what was then prophesied.

A notice will be found on page 4 announcing that all powers hitherto held from the Egyptian Estates Ltd. by Mr. Montagu Summers have been revoked and that henceforwared Mr. Bummers has no power or authority to act in the name or on behalf of the company.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan has left for Pineus on board his yacht "Ancona."
Mohamed Mohsen Pasha left yesterday by the Norddeutscher Lloyd steamer for Europe.

Mr. Mansfeldt de Cardonnel Findlay, C.M.G., the recently appointed British Minister at the Court of Saxony, in succession to Viscount Gough, has taken a fine villa residence in the Wienerstrasse at Dresden.
Among those who left for Europe by the S.S. "Schleswig" of the Norddeutscher Lloyd line were Prince Youssef Bey Kamel, and de Martino Pasha.
Sir James Blyth, one of the newly created lieers, has taken the title of Baron Blyth of Bly th wood, Essex.
Mr. C. H. Schueller and the Misses Schueller left Alexandria for Europe yesterday hy the S.S. "Schleswig."
The Rev. T. A. Branthwaite, D.D. LL.D,, British Chaplain of Odessa and the Crimea, has been appointed rector of St Mary's and head of the Bishop of Jerusalem's College, Cairo.

The following passengers left for Europe yesterday by tho Norddeutscher Lloyd S.S. "Schleswig" :—Mr. Boubolis, Mrs. P. Agnan-diadan, Artin Pasha, Mrs. Artin Pasha, Miss Artin, Mr. M. Braun, Mr. L. Cretton, Mr. Finck, Mr. Friedr. Grediger, Mr. Riad Ghali, Mr. Giglio, Hussein Hassan Bey, Mr. Here* bruch, Mr. A. Hiokling, Mr. Ch. Johnson; Mahmoud Bey Kamel, Mr. and Mrs. Kraeoek, Mr. Halim J. Khouzam, Mr. and Mrs. Logan, Major G.B. Macauley, Mrs. Mohamed Pasha Mohsen, Mr. Poller, Major Wm. B. Rochester, Mr. N. Rousso, Mr. Albert Reiser, Mohamed Soubki bey, Mrs. Soubki Bey, Mr. Mohamed Tewfik Sakib, Omar Bey Sultan, Mr. A. Toledo, Mr. J. M. Tothil), Mr. Windsor, Mr. Hugo Wourlisch, Tewfik Boy Zaher.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujour@ hui @ 11h, 1/2 am).

Le marché. n'a pas présenté ce matin la méme animation que vendredi dernier et la cote a été moins soutenue pour les valeurs dirigeantes, mais la tendance, s'il faut en croire la généralité des intéressés, -demeure ferme avec unedemande de bon augure pour l'avenir. Il y a des acheteurs, dit-on, et en général ils doivent payer un prix supérieur & celui coté. Bref, les acheteurs affluent, tandis que les ven- deurs se sont éclipsés. Nous avons déjA signalé trop de fois les raisons qui déterminent ces revirements haussiers chaque fin de mois pour y revenir.

Les affaires ont porté spécialement sur Agricole, qui a cloturé offerte 4 7 7/8 et sur la National Bank qui a perdu 1/4 de livre & 19 3/16. La Daira Sanieh a, an contraire, gagné 1/4 de livre 4 14 1/8 et. PObligation Crédit Foncier 5 fr. l'ancienne 4 306 et 8 fr. 50 la nouvelle 4 264 1/2. La Delta Light a été inscrite A 9 1/2 ex coupon.

En ce qui concerne |'Obligation Crédit Fon- cier, la hausse ininterrompue dont ce titre bénéficie depuis quelques jours serait occa} sionnée, sil faut en croire un bruit acerédité en bourse, & un découvert qu'on cherche a égorger. Si ce bruit est fondé, il est probable que le recul,constaté récemment sera totale- ment regagné, et au-deld.

Une autre valeur qui progresse de fagon inattendue, aprés de longs mois de baisse et de marasme, c'est la Building Lands dont le prix remonte d'un coup de 2 1/16 & 2 7/16-1/2. La raison qu'on allégue pour cette reprisa soudaine est le rachat par la société elle-méme de ses titres dépréciés, |
En hausse encore les Tramways d'Alexan- drie de 136 4 137 les Privilégiées et de 280 i 282 les Dividendes, |'Alexandria Water de 10 5/8 & 10 3/4, la Land Bank de 6 13/16 a 7 1/16.

Parmiles petites valeurs la Delta Land, trés soutenue, s'avance de 1 7/16 4 1 1/2, Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 20/9 4 21, PAnglo-Egyptian Allotment de 1 7/8 4 2 l'action et de 50 4 60 P.T. la part de fondateur, les Cotton Ginners de 11/4 41 5/16, et la Levico de 1/4 a 5/16. Lia part de fondateur de cette dernitre s'inscrit 4 4 livres. On achéte la fondateur Unitedal 3/4.
En revanche, les Nungovich Hotels revien- nent de 14 4 13, l'action nouvelle Comptoir de 25/164 21/4, Union Fonciére de 4 1/2 a 4 7/16, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 4 1/16 a 4.
Les Estates sont trés sontenus A 1/2-9/16. La Cassa di Sconto reprend: de 25 & 26.
Le reste de la cote demeure sans changement.

Ainsi que nous l'avons déja dit au début de ce bulletin, bien que l'ensemble dela cote ne soit pas aussi satisfaisant que vendredi der- nier, l'impression générale est meilleure. Les acheteurs ne s'esquivent pas de facon aussi absolue que naguére et si pour certains titres, comme la National Bank, 'les transactions ne s'effectuent qu'au prix d'une réduction, pour d'autres, au contraire, les acquéreurs acceptent de payer un surplus.
Le tout est desavoirs'il nes'agit pas d'un simple découvert ou d'une réaction passa- gére, ou si p aIIHOEREON est appelde & ce consolider.

div.head: Cireulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny

Le taux de l'escompte libre & Londres se maintient & 3 5/8 pour cent.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidd anglais est remont^ hier de 3/8 a 83 1/8. L'Unifide est rest^e invari^e & 101 3/4. I^a National Bank | a encore gagn£ 1 /8 M 19 5/8. L'Agricole s'est maintenue a 8 1/8, ainsi que la Daira Sa-nieh & 14 1/4. La Delta Light a avanc£ de 1/8^9 5/8.
A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptian a retrograde de 1 franc a 688, de m$me qne la Banque d'Athenes & 108 et les Lots Tures a 164.

Ici, le marche n'a pas W aussi anim£, aussi actif quTiier. Il a <k*bute, il est vrai, en tendance tr£s soutenuepour ne pas tarder & inollir quelque peu par suite de realisations que les plus-values suivies acquises ces jours derniers devaient forement provoquer. Mais cette lourdeur ne s'est gu^re maintenue et des de mandes ont d6terminl le raffermissement de la cote en cloture.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na tional, que nous avions laiss^e hier ft 19 9/16, a avanc*1 i 20, gagnant pr&s d'une demi-livre L*Agricole s'est consolid^e A 8 1/16. La Cassa di Bconto a avanc£ A 35. Les parts de fon-datebr de la Soci£t£ G^ndrale Egyptienne sont remont^es i 30.

Les obligations & lots anciennes du Credit Foncier se sont maintenues & 309 ; las nou-velles ont r^trograxU a 263. La Daira Sanieh a passdde 14 1/8 a 14 1/4-5/16. L'Allotment a progress^ a 2 1/16-1 8 ;sa part est revenue a 51. 1/Enterprise and Development a 6W moins bien tenue & 8 et sa part i 10. Ler# Heliopolis se sont inscrits en progr&s a 242 et leur part A 10 3/4. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire se sont alourdies A 184.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hdteli&res, les Nunj^oyich ont 6t4 negliges A 13 1/4. Les Egyptian opt progress^ A 5 1/8. Les Ritz ont avanc<£ib<H/8.

Parwi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land sont cestui i 1 5/8. Les Estates se sont raf-fermis & 0 5/8, les New Egyptian & 12 sk 9 et les Markets & 25 sh.9. Les Khedivial Mail ordinaires ont atteint 22 ah. Les Salt and Soda se sont tans^s & 16 sh.6. Les Ghezireh Man siona ont traiUes A 0 1/4-5/16.
L'assembl&g^rale ordinaire de l'Egyptian
Delta Light Railways, qui s'est fenu^ A, JUpn-Juillet cokihhU & vot3 tlite'
tioD autorisant les administrateurs de la Com-pagnie A signer avec le gouvernement Egyptien la convention modifiimt l'aote de concession du chentdn de fer d'H^lonam

Dans son discours, Sir Charles Fremantle, qui pr&sidait la reunion, a constate que e'est la premiere fois depuis sa fondation que la Soci^td a pu r^partir un dividende aussi ^levd que 5 1/2 pour cent sur ses actions pri-vikgi^es.

Pour ce qui est du railway d'Hdlouan, le president, a annonc^ que cette ligne serait prolonged d'environ six kilometres dans la direction du Sud et desservirait une region adja-cente au Nil dont le developpement a consi-derablement attir^ l'attention en ces temps derniers.
Le bilan du ler semestre de la Banque d'Ath£nes, qui vient d'etre public, accuse un
btWfice net de drachmes 2,350,000 contre 1,242,000 pour la pfriode correspondante de 1936.

Ces bdn^fices ont permis la rdpartftion d'un dividende provisoire de 4 drachmes par action sur les 400,000 actions actuellement en circulation, ce qui a absorbs 1,600,000 drachmes. Il a reports A nouveau Dr. 750,000, dont ces actions Wn^ficieront pour le second semes tre.
Il y a lieu de noter que la somme de Dr. 242,000 reports A nouveau A la fin du ler se-mestre 1906 ne repr&entait que Dr. 0.74 pour chacune des 300,000 actions alors en cours.
Ces r&iultats font pr^voir que, malgr<$ l'aug-mentation du capital, le dividende total de l'ann^e sera, sinon sup^rieur, au moins ^gal A celui de l'exercice prudent, soit environ 9 francs par action.

L'assembtee gdn^rale ordinaire de la Soci^t^ Anonyine des Grands Garages d'Egypte, qui s'est tenue au si£ge social au Caire le 23 Juillet oourant, a approuvi* le rapport du conseil d'administration, ainsi que les eoinptes et bilan de l'exercice 1906-1907. Le dividende a fix6 A P.E. 7 par action.

En rendant compte de l'assembltfe generate ordinaire de l'Egyptian Estates Co., le journal " Telegraphos ''d'Alexandrie raconte quecette Soci£t£ aurait propose la r^siliation du contrat d'achat du Savoy Hotel en offrant d'abandon-ner le premier versement de 40,003 livres (1^'jA effectu^, plus un d6dit de 20,000 livres.
Le "Telegraphos " fait remarquer quecette proposition n'a pas dfl apparemment. avoir des suites du moment qu elle n'a pas communique A l'assemblde.

div.p: Les repetitions du grand concert Wagnei se suivent chaque jour et dimanche matin, comme nous l'avons ddjA, annoned, aura lieu l'ex^cotion de pareils chefs d'oeuvre.

div.head:
TROUBLE IN MOROCCO.
HOLY WAR PROCLAIMED.
FLIGHT OF EUROPEANS.

div.p: The natives, who are discontented with the port and railway works at Casablanca, have invaded the town and murdered five Frenchmen, two Italians, and a Spaniard. They then pillaged the shops and burned the bodies.
The natives of Casablanca proclaim a holy war.' The Europeans, who remained in the town have fled. (Havas)

div.head:
THE CROMER GRANT.
HOME PRESS APPROVAL.

div.p: All the newspapers, including the "Tribune," "Daily Chronicle" and "Daily News," join in extolling Lord Cromer's work. His meritorious services they say are amply deserving of the mark of public gratitude. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE CONSTAUBLARY MUTINY.
TROOPS IN READINESS.

div.p: The advent of the Highlanders has reassured the public. Trains are in readiness in ^Dublin to convey further troops here, but the authorities believe that they will not be required unless there is further disaffection among the Constabulary, which is not expected.
The Middlesex Regiment, with a maxim gun section, arrived here this afternoon. There are now over 6000 troops in the city. (Reuter)

div.head:
U.S.A. AND JAPAN.
CROSSING THE BORDER.

div.p: The State Department has opened negocia-tions with Mexico with a view to stopping the influx of Japanese coolies into the United States across the border. (Reuter)
Friction has arisen here through the landing of numbers of Japanese from Honolulu.

Kent beat Derbyshire by an innings and 146 runs. Somerset beat Gloucestershire by 6 wickets. Hampshire beat Middlesex by 161 runs. The following matches have been drawn: Leicestershire v. Warwickshire; Essex v Northamptonshire ; and Surrey v. Worcestershire.
(Reuter)
1. Royal Dream ; 2. Plum Tree ; 3. Hongkong 11 ran. Won by half a length. Four lengths between second and third. Betting ; 3 to 1 Royal Dream ; 9 to 1 Plum Tree ; 6 to 1 Hongkong. (Reuter)

div.head: THE NAVAL ESTIMATES.
div.p: House of Commons. — Speaking on the Naval Estimates, Mr. Robertson in a general review of the naval situation concluded by refuting the statements with regard to chees-paring in connection with repairs and other matters. He repeated that'a third battleship would be laid down unless the result of the Hague Confeience justified the cancelling of it.
(Reuter)

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market.

In our last article we mentioned that there was no probability of another heavy American drain on our gold resources this .autumn, such as had to be met last year. This statement is confirmed by a message from New York this week, which states that the influential Treasury officials there have quietly notified the leading Wall Street bankers that if they hold down Wall Street speculation for the next two months, the Government will deposit enough money in the national banks later to finance the autumn crop movement. Although there is a condition attached to the promise, which may or may not be kept by the bankers, there is no doubt that the United States Treasury will do their best to avoid the financial squeeze which has been such a feature of the cotton harvest season during the past few years.

This, it is unnecessary to point out, will have an important bearing on our gold position here, in view of the heavy demand which will be made by Egypt for the moving of the crop. An increased bank rate is to be avoided if possible, and if the reserve continues to be augmented at the present rate, and America is not an extensive importer of gold as in past years, it may be possible to finance the Egyptian crop without the necessity of raising the Bank's minimum.

With this week's addition of £431,000, the reserve now stands at £25,549,000, which is only £140,000 lower than at this period last year. The ratio to liabilities has risen 1J to 47£ per cent., which brings it within 1 per cent, of last year's figure. A net influx of £409,000 from abroad was accompanied by a small return of coin from internal circulation, and the stock of bullion is thus increased by £497,000.

There is now rather more demand for money accomnuxlation consequent on the approach of the end of the month, and yesterday day to day and weekly loans were quoted 2| to 2j per cent. For three months' fine bills as much as 5jf was obtained.
The silver market has again been very firm, and the quotation has further advanced | being now quoted 31 £d.

It is unfortunate that the prospective arrangement by which the trade difficulties connected with the crisis in Egypt would have been tided over by the private liquidation of the estates involved, has fallen through, forbad this scheme gone forward there is no doubt that it would have done much towards restoring things to a normal condition, and would have considerably helped the market. The announcement that the arrangement cannot be carried out has naturally led to a revival of anxiety, especially in Manchester, but when it is pointed out that all those interested are well able to stand any suspension that may arise, it will be seen that there is no cause for undue pessimism. This fact ought to be sufficient to prevent any serious relapse in stocks and shares.

That the Egyptian share market is taking a hopeful view of the situation will be gathered from our report below. This week the tone has shown a decided improvement, and the rise in prices is, in the circumstances, a matter of much satisfaction. It is to be hoped that this feeling of confidence may continue, ami that we may be saved a further set-back.
In the market for general securities dealings are on a small scale, and are likely to continue restricted until after the fortnightly settlement.

The most unsatisfactory feature is the weakness of gilt-edged stocks. This 'section seems to possess absolutely no stability, and Consols are now quoted at a price which would have appeared inconceivable a few years ago.

The premier security goes ftom bad to worse, and there appears to be no limit to the liquidation. Yesterday's loss of | brought the, price down to 83, 7/16. They leave of to day with a recovery of 1/16.

It is somewhat difficult to understand why only £2,000,000 of the £4,000,000 issued by the South Manchurian Railway should have 2 been subscribed by the public. The only explanation that can be put forward is the present unsatisfactory state of financial business, j The loan was unconditionally guaranteed by j the Japanese Government, and is a perfectly sound security, so that there appears to be 1 little justification for the criticisms which have been levelled against the Government for ! bringing out the issue at the present juncture.

After the announcement of the result of the : issue, the new scrip went to 1 f discount, but this price quickly brought in buyers, and the quotation closed firm last night at fj discount Japanese Fours and the Second Four-and-a Half, however, gave way J. The scrip has been : steady to-day, but other issues have shed fa.

Further Railway dividends have been announced this week. The South Eastern declare- 1 tion is at the rate of 1 per cent, the same as . last year, and the balance forward shows a reduction of £2,206, at £7,000. The Chatham Company declare a dividend on the Arbitration Preference of £1 :5 :6 for the half year as against £1 :8 :6 last year. The Lancashire 1 and Yorkshire announcement Caused some dissatisfaction, it being expected that as the gross traffic had increased by over £60,000 an increased dividend and carry forward would have been declared. The rate remains at 4 per cent., and the balance is increased by only £1,000.

The Taff Vale dividend remains at 4 per cent, but the carry forward is increased by £5.000. The London and South Western yesterday declared a dividend of 4 per cent, carrying forward £24,900. The rate is the same as in 1906, but the forward balance shows a decrease of £1,322.
The market for these shares is still very idle, and quotations where they move at all generally follow a downward course.

Yesterday the featare was the flatness of Chatham Ordinary, which shed g to 11. The South Western announcement was considered quite satisfactory, and the price improved to 44, but closed unchanged at 43j. Caledonian stocks were sold, the Preference declining i and the Deferred J. The market has continued idle to-day.

To-day the Great Northern declared a dividend of 3 percent., per annum on the Ordinary, 2 per cent, on the Preferred con verted Ordinary and 3 per cent, to "B" stock, carrying forward £61,646. Last year the dividend was the same and the carry forward £51,390. The North Eastern have increased their dividend from 5| to 5j per cent carrying £101,000 against £62,627.

American railway shares appear to be the most active point in the "House," and have been largely dealt in. Chief interest has centred in the Harriman issues. Yesterday Southern Pacific which opened with a parity of 92 9/16, and Unions touched 152$, after opening at 150 7/16. Profit taking in the afternoon put prices down somewhat, Southern Pacific falling to 92 and Union Pacific to 150£.
To-day the tone has not been quite so favourable Unions have lost J and Southern Pacific J.

The tone in the Egyptian market is distinctly better, and prices are once more on the upgrade. In view of the disappointment which has been caused by the failure of the arrangement re the trade difficulties, this firmness is noted with much gratification as a sign of the confidence entertained that the troubles will be overcome without serious disturbance

National Bank of Egypt have advanced steadily to 19^-J, and Agricultural Bank are up to 7J-8, the Preference remaining firm at 9-|. The investment buying of Delta Preference has continued. The price tonight is 9| x.d. There are large orders in the market to take stock should there be any reaction. Delta Land and Investment are the turn better at lf-J.

Egyptian Estates after being 10/- close firm at f, after the annual meeting, referred to * elsewhere. Khedivial Mail have been dealt in to some extent at 19/6-19/9, and 20/-S. closing rather sellers yesterday at the latter price. They leave off to-day at l-J, Daira are better at 14and the Deferred at 75-80.

Agricultural Bank of Egypt Founders shares, which have not been mentioned for a long time, have changed hands at 850 and 830. Imnd Bank of Egypt are at 6 § j, after being 6 $-7 J, and Union Fonciere 4 j £. Salt and Soda are round about 17/6, and Egyptian Markets 26/6 27/6. There has been some demand for United Egyptian Land at 7/16, but not much business has resulted. Anglo-Egyptian Bank are still a dull market at 12 J 13

The mining section is quiet in view of the carry-over tomorrow. The tone is on the whole fairly satisfactory, however, and one or two shares have been quite active during the past day or two. Yesterday Premiers spurted 18/16 to 9 i and Tanganyikas also showed a firmer oppearance, and advanced 3/32 to 4 j.
To day several Kaffirs show improvement Egyptian mining shares are unmentioned.
Egyptian Mines Exploration are quoted l/-s. and Nile Valley J.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report
Liverpool, July 25.

There lias been no improvement in the demand for Egyptians this week. The sales continue to be small, and quotations are reduced J plb. for both Brown and Uppers, except Fine Brown which is exceptionally | plb. lower.
Trading in Futures has been .limited, and the following are the latest quotations :— July 10.52 Oct. 10.43 Jan. 10.32 Aug. 10.47 Nov. 10.41 Feb. 10.31 Sep. 10.45 Dec. 10.35 Mar. 10.31

American Futures. The market this week has been quiet in tone with very little business doing outside of the Professional trading ; there have been frequent fluctuations and to-day's closing values are 2@ 4i points higher than those of last Thursday. The condition of the Crop is the supreme factor, and although there is of course much divergence in the reports received, the weather generally has been .considered favorable. The last 2 or 3 days however, high temperatures with a dry atmosphere have just indicated a source of anxiety which would become serious if prolonged.

div.head: MOTOR BUSES IN EGYPT.
div.p: Recently, after running for some months, the motor buses were temporarily withdrawn from the streets of Alexandria. Last week motor omnibuses to the value of £800,000 have been withdrawn from the streets of London and yesterday the shareholders of the London Power Omnibus Company resolved on liquidation. According to one's prejudice, it is permissible to say either "Good heavens I" or "Good riddanceT' But is is nofc so easy to be sure that motor-omnibuses have had a fair chance, or that the best possible type of 'bus has been running. This new method of locomotion is in the first experimental stage ; and its fate has been to be tried at a time when regulation of the street traffic of all sorts is in a loose and deplorable confusion. New companies plunged into the confusion without knowing at all what they would be allowed to do, and with a sort of notion that they had to conquer a special right of way. Their tares were fixed on a basis of sanguine expectation accordingly. Perhaps the 'buses were of too heavy a type. Perhaps it uas preposterous to think of forcing the pace of.&ny kind of traffic.

The significant thing about this attempt to quicken traffic is that, even if the motor bus companies were to throw up the sponge tomorrow, nobody would assume that the last word had been said on the subject. The motor bus is the conveyance of the future and because it has not been very successful in its beginnings, it by no means proves that it will be a failure.

div.head: ONE DISAPPOINTMENT SUFFICIENT.
div.p: The grandson of a man who had befriended Russell Sage called one day, asking for a loan of $10, promising that he would repay in a week's time. Sage let him have the money without undue fuss. At the hour appointed the young man reappeared, laid the $10 before the millionaire and departed. Soon afterwards he called again, saying that he wanted $100 for a sound and excellent investment. If Sage would let him have the money he would refund with interest upon a given date. The old man beamed kindly upon his yourig friend. "My boy," he said, "you disappointed me once, and. I don't want you to do it again." The young man gasped "Yes," the other went on, "you paid me back that $10 when I never expected you would. Now, if I let you have $100, I should expect you to pay it back, and you wouldn't. One disappointment is enough at my time of life, my boy." And he pleasantly bowed his visitor out of the office. — Toronto Saturday Night,
